===Etymology 1===

[[File:Karwats.jpg|thumb|A scourge ''(noun {{senseno|en|whip}})'' [[exhibit#Verb|exhibited]] in a [[museum#Noun|museum]].]]

From {{inh|en|enm|scourge|t=a lash, whip, scourge; affliction, calamity; person who causes affliction or calamity; shoot of a vine}},<ref>{{R:MED Online|entry=scǒurǧe|pos=n|id=MED39002}}</ref> and then either:

* from {{der|en|xno|scorge}}, {{m|xno|escorge}}, {{m|xno|escurge}}, or {{der|en|fro|scurge}}, {{m|fro|escourge}}, {{m|fro|escorge}}, {{m|fro|escorgiee}}, {{m|fro|escurge}} (modern {{cog|fr|escourgée|t=(''archaic'') whip made of leather strips}}), either:
** from {{der|en|VL.|*excoriāta|t=strip of hide; a scourge}}, from {{der|en|LL.|excoriāre}}, the {{glossary|present}} {{glossary|active}} {{glossary|infinitive}} of {{m|LL.|excoriō|t=to strip the skin from, to skin}}, from {{der|en|la|ex-|pos={{glossary|prefix}} meaning ‘away; out’}} + {{m|la|corium|t=skin; hide, leather}} (ultimately from {{der|en|ine-pro|*(s)ker-|t=to cut off, sever; to divide, separate}});<ref>{{R:OED Online|pos=n|id=2525733037|date=July 2023}}</ref> or
** from {{der|en|la|ex-|pos={{glossary|intensifying}} prefix}} + {{m|la|corrigia|t=a whip}} (from {{m|la|corrigō|t=to make right, correct; to reform}}, ultimately from {{der|en|ine-pro|*h₃reǵ-|t=to righten; to straighten}});<ref>{{R:Lexico|pos=n}}</ref> or
* from {{der|en|enm|scourgen|pos=verb}} (see [[#Etymology 2|etymology 2]]).

## A [[person#Noun|person]] or [[thing]] [[regard#Verb|regarded]] as an [[agent]] of [[divine#Adjective|divine]] [[punishment]].
##* {{RQ:Marlorat Golding Revelation|chapter=2|verse=3|folio=32|verso=1|passage=And therfore the faithfull had neede of inuincible conſtancie and incredible pacience, that they may know them to be gods '''squorges''', and the inſtrumentes of his wrath, {{...}}}}
##* {{RQ:Coryat Crudities|chapter=My Obseruations of the Most Glorious, Peerelesse, and Mayden Citie of Venice:{{nb...|I Call It Mayden because It was Neuer Conquered.}}|lines=14–18|page=162|passage=Againe not long after this euen ſhortly after the death of ''[[w:Alaric I|Alaricus]]'' came that ''Flagellum Dei'' that '''ſcourge''' of God into Italy, ''{{w|Attila}}'' King of the Hunnes, and ſpoyled the country vvith maruailous hoſtility in the time of the Emperour ''[[w:Marcian|Martian]]''.}}
##* {{RQ:Gibbon Roman Empire|volume=III|chapter=The Character, Conquests, and Court of Attila, King of the Huns—Death of [[w:Theodosius II|Theodosius the Younger]]—Elevation of {{w|Marcian}} to the Empire of the East|page=368|passage=[I]f {{w|Attila}} equalled the hoſtile ravages of [[w:Timur|Tamerlane]], either the Tartar or the Hun might deſerve the epithet of the {{small|'''Scourge''' of God}}.}}
##* {{RQ:Shelley Cenci|scene=i|page=48|passage=[H]e, / As he is wont, came to upbraid and curse, / Mocking our poverty, and telling us / Such was God's '''scourge''' for disobedient sons.}}
##* {{RQ:Lawrence Porcupine|page=157|passage=Yet true destructive power is power just the same as constructive. Even {{w|Attila}}, the '''Scourge''' of God, who helped to scourge the Roman world out of existence, was great with power. He was the '''scourge''' of ''God''; not the '''scourge''' of the League of Nations, hired and paid in cash.}}
## A [[source#Noun|source]] of [[persistent]] (and often [[widespread]]) [[pain#Noun|pain]] and [[suffering#Noun|suffering]] or [[trouble#Noun|trouble]], such as a [[cruel#Adjective|cruel]] [[ruler]], [[disease#Noun|disease]], [[pestilence]], or [[war#Noun|war]].
##: {{ux|en|Graffiti is the '''scourge''' of building owners everywhere.}}
##* {{RQ:Shakespeare Henry 6-1|act=IV|scene=ii|page=111|column=2|passage=Thou ominous and fearefull Ovvle of death, / Our Nations terror, and their bloody '''ſcourge''', / The period of thy Tyranny approacheth, / On vs thou canſt not enter but by death: {{...}}}}
##* {{RQ:Shakespeare Richard 3 Q1|act=I|scene=iv|sig=&#91;C4&#93;|verso=1|page=32|passage=[W]hat '''ſcourge''' for periury, / Can this darke monarchy afford falſe Clarence, {{...}}}}
##* {{RQ:Montaigne Florio Essayes|book=III|chapter=Of Experience|page=661|passage=Intemperance is the plague of ſenſualitie; and temperance is not her '''ſcourge''', but rather her ſeaſoning.}}
##* {{RQ:Shakespeare Coriolanus|act=II|scene=iii|page=12|column=2|passage=You haue bin a '''ſcourge''' to her enemies, you haue bin a Rod to her Friends, you haue not indeede loued the Common people.}}
##* {{RQ:Thomson Winter|year=1768|page=181|lines=466–469|passage=[[w:Cimon|{{smallcaps|Cimon}}]] {{...}} vvhoſe genius, riſing ſtrong, / Shook off the load of young debauch; abroad / The '''ſcourge''' of ''Perſian'' pride, at home the friend / Of every vvorth and every ſplendid art; {{...}}}}
##* {{RQ:Mary Shelley Frankenstein|volume=II|chapter=I|page=30|passage=On you it rests, whether I quit for ever the neighbourhood of man, and lead a harmless life, or become the '''scourge''' of your fellow-creatures, and the author of your own speedy ruin.}}
##* {{RQ:Shelley Poetical Works|edition=revised|volume=II|poem=Charles I|scene=ii|page=385|passage={{...}} I speak it not / As loving parliaments, which, as they have been / In the right hand of bold bad mighty kings / The '''scourges''' of the bleeding Church, I hate.}}
##* {{RQ:Ouida In Maremma|volume=I|chapter=II|page=23|passage=[H]e had become a monster of cruelty, having in him the same temper as of old made the tyrants of Padova and Verona and Brescia the '''scourges''' of their generation.}}
##* {{RQ:Economist|title=Towards the end of poverty|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20230526160410/https://www.economist.com/leaders/2013/06/01/towards-the-end-of-poverty|date=1 June 2013|volume=407|issue=8838|page=11|passage=America's poverty line is $63 a day for a family of four. In the richer parts of the emerging world $4 a day is the poverty barrier. But poverty's '''scourge''' is fiercest below $1.25{{nb...}}: people below that level live lives that are poor, nasty, brutish and short.}}

===Etymology 2===
From {{inh|en|enm|scourgen|t=to whip, scourge; to afflict; to punish}},<ref>{{R:MED Online|entry=
scǒurǧen|pos=v|id=MED39003}}</ref> and then either:

* from {{m|enm|scourge|pos=noun}} + {{m|enm|-en|pos={{glossary|suffix}} forming {{glossary|infinitive}}s of {{glossary|verb}}s}};<ref>{{R:MED Online|entry=-en|pos=''suf.''(3)|noformat=1|id=MED13518}}</ref> or
* from {{der|en|xno|escorger}}, and {{der|en|fro|escorgier|t=to whip, to scourge}}, which are either:
** from {{der|en|xno|scorge}}, {{m|xno|escorge|pos=noun}}, etc., or {{der|en|fro|scurge}}, {{m|fro|escourge|pos=noun}}, etc. + {{m|fro|-er|pos=suffix forming infinitives of first-{{glossary|conjugation}} verbs}};<ref name="OED">{{R:OED Online|pos=v|id=2537771875|date=September 2023}}</ref> or
** from {{der|en|VL.|*excorrigiō}}, from {{der|en|la|ex-|pos={{glossary|intensifying}} prefix}} + {{m|la|corrigia|t=a whip}};<ref>{{R:Lexico|pos=v}}</ref> or
** directly from {{der|en|LL.|excoriāre}}.<ref name="OED"/>

See further at [[#Etymology 1|etymology 1]].
